results.title: Igor and the dancing stallions (Yugoslavia)
results.creator_credit: Peter Rowe, Fred Harris, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Sunrise Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World cultures and youth”.
Focuses on sixteen-year-old boy Igor Lang who for two years has been a stableboy on the famed Lipica horse farm in Yugoslavia, training his mount, Maestozo, in the graceful steps of dressage. When Maestozo suffers a leg injury due to Igor’s handling, the boy loses hope of participating in an upcoming celebration. But good care heals the wound and Igor and Maestozo play their part in the program that marks the farm’s 400th anniversary. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Rowe, Fred Harris, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Sunrise Films

results.title: Ming-Oi the magician (Hong Kong)
results.creator_credit: Deepa Mehta, Paul Saltzman, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Sunrise Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World cultures and youth”.
Focuses on a sixteen-year-old Hong Kong girl, a magician’s apprentice. who works hard to perfect the illusions of Chinese magic and juggling.

results.title: Yohannes the silversmith (Ethiopia)
results.creator_credit: Richard Gilbert, Paul Quigley and Sunrise Film's Ltd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World cultures and youth”.
This film highlights the customs and traditions of villagers in Ethiopia, as well as evidence of cultural change. It focuses on a twelve-year-old boy who decides to learn the craft of silver smithing to earn an income to help pay for his tertiary education.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Gilbert, Paul Quigley and Sunrise Film’s Ltd

results.title: Lena the glassblower: Sweden
results.creator_credit: Peter Rowe, Fred Harris, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Sunrise Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World cultures and youth”.
The story of Lena, a 17-year-old girl who decides to become a glassblower against the wishes of her parents, who want her to take up tertiary education. As well as dealing positively with this conflict, the film shows many aspects of the craft of glassblowing - in particular, that carried out at the Orrefors establishment in Sweden. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Lee's parasol (Thailand)
results.creator_credit: Paul Saltzman and Sunrise Films Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World cultures and youth”.
15 year old Lee Nakhampa is making a beautiful parasol as a ‘gift of love’ for her cousin, a Buddhist monk. Carefully designing and painting it, she leaves it to dry but returns to discover her employer has reluctantly given it to an important customer. Lee is upset, but recovers to quickly paint another parasol. We see her present it to her cousin during the ceremonies at the colourful Buddhist festival.

results.title: Julia the gourdcarver: Peru
results.creator_credit: Paul Saltzman and Sunrise Films Ltd
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World cultures and youth”.
Four thousand years ago in the high mountains of the Andes, the Inca Indians began carving gourds to record their legends and history. Today Julia Sanabria, 11 years old, continues the ancient craft taught by her uncle. She carves her own life story on a gourd and takes it to the market town of Huancayo. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Taking control
results.description:
The women in Thelma & Louise and Promising Young Woman seek their own justice because society won’t believe or listen to them. When the system fails, they fight back. The characters on this screen are part of that cinematic tradition, which stretches from exploitation films like Foxy Brown (1974) and Ms .45 (1982) to today. In that time, female characters have triumphed despite being disbelieved. Ripley (Sigourney Weaver) could have avoided killing the queen in Aliens (1986) if the men in the first film had listened to her warnings. In Terminator 2: Judgement Day (1991), Sarah Connor has to escape an asylum because no one believes she averted an AI apocalypse in the first film.

These future visions are grounded in the past and present. The women in The Nightingale (2018) and The Drover’s Wife (2021) arm themselves against male violence and racism in colonial Australia. But strength is more than physical. Law and Order: SVU’s Olivia Benson (Mariska Hargitay) puts the “lights out” of her attacker but also fights for victims, while Once Were Warriors (1994) follows Beth (Rena Owen) learning she can “survive anything” after tragedy. In A Fantastic Woman (2017), a trans woman battles a legal system that discriminates against her and in Total Control (2019–) Senator Alex Irving (Deborah Mailman) stands up to her political opponents, knowing her push for social justice is “bigger” than their rivalry.
description_for_label:
The women in Thelma & Louise and Promising Young Woman seek their own justice because society won’t believe or listen to them. When the system fails, they fight back. The characters on this screen are part of that cinematic tradition, which stretches from exploitation films like Foxy Brown (1974) and Ms .45 (1982) to today. In that time, female characters have triumphed despite being disbelieved. Ripley (Sigourney Weaver) could have avoided killing the queen in Aliens (1986) if the men in the first film had listened to her warnings. In Terminator 2: Judgement Day (1991), Sarah Connor has to escape an asylum because no one believes she averted an AI apocalypse in the first film.

These future visions are grounded in the past and present. The women in The Nightingale (2018) and The Drover’s Wife (2021) arm themselves against male violence and racism in colonial Australia. But strength is more than physical. Law and Order: SVU’s Olivia Benson (Mariska Hargitay) puts the “lights out” of her attacker but also fights for victims, while Once Were Warriors (1994) follows Beth (Rena Owen) learning she can “survive anything” after tragedy. In A Fantastic Woman (2017), a trans woman battles a legal system that discriminates against her and in Total Control (2019–) Senator Alex Irving (Deborah Mailman) stands up to her political opponents, knowing her push for social justice is “bigger” than their rivalry.

results.title: [Release prints compilation]
results.brief_description:
1. Wall to Wall Wool - Documents the process of wool carpet production from design illustrations of a bunch of flowers to the manufacture of finished carpet with similar design. Primarily focuses on the many types of machinery used to create the carpet. Contains nice images of a carpet-making factory, specifically the colourful flower-patterned carpet juxtaposed within an industrial backdrop. Good ‘The End’. (12m 44sec)

  2. Melbourne: Festival City - Made by the Victorian Tourist Development Authority in the 1960s. Essentially an ad for Melbourne, focusing on the ‘highly popular’ Moomba Festival. Great images of large crowds watching the Moomba parade as well as having fun on rides, watching watersports and eating/drinking (including Latte drinkers). Also shows the ‘recently completed’ Sydney Myer Music Bowl, footage of a game of football at the MCG and highlights Melbourne as the ‘Fashion Capital’. Nice closing shot of the city, focusing on St. Pauls and a Fed Square-less Flinders St, as well as the Yarra. Good titles and ‘The End’. (10 mins)

  3. Hydatids - Australian Wool Bureau production. Highlights the dangers of Hydatid disease and the ease of which it can be both contracted and negated. This includes washing hands after having contact with dogs and boiling all sheep offal before feeding it to dogs. Contains footage of a farmer gutting a sheep and cute diagrams of how the hydatids disease can spread from sheep to dogs to humans. (10 mins)
